prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Increasingly, North American businesses are becoming the targets of economic espionage from abroad. Particular care should be taken when company representatives travel abroad. A number of tactics have been employed in recent years to obtain valuable business information, including outright theft, bribery and aggressive wiretapping. Extra care should also be taken during negotiations and transactions involving technology or information. The following principles should be kept in mind:
Assume that overseas calls can be monitored, particularly those involving newer forms of communication such as computer, cellular or satellite links.
Be aware that accommodations and facilities—even security boxes, couriers, phones and postal services—may not have the same privacy standards to which you are accustomed.
Be prepared for vastly different business, industry and ethical standards.
Meet your business needs by acquiring knowledge of foreign cultures, languages, customs, tactics and legal systems (particularly those relating to intellectual property issues).
On the positive side, increasing attention is being brought to the issue of international trade secret protection. In that regard, see section 7:28.
